I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Macroeconomic  context.  Sri  Lanka  is  at  a  pivotal  economic  and  demographic 
crossroads. In 2018, it crossed the threshold into an upper-middle-income country (UMIC) with a 
per capita income of $4,060.1 The new government aims to transform itself into a globally 
competitive and inclusive knowledge economy to sustain and further enhance economic growth. 
The main pillars include prioritizing human capital development, strengthening industry and 
service sectors, transforming  agriculture, and infusing new technology to enhance productivity.2 
Ageing population and increasing dependency ratio in Sri Lanka threaten to strain economic 
resources.3 Sri Lanka’s competitiveness will depend on optimizing its workforce potential. This 
entails improving health and education of its youth to lift productivity and participation rates, 
closing the gender gap in the labor market, and reallocating labor across sectors. Building a 
healthy, diversified, and agile workforce — receptive to lifelong learning, able to adapt, innovate, 
and leverage new technologies — is key to the government’s development goal.  Thus, the new 
government has prioritized integrated and transformative reforms in the education and health 
sectors to boost human capital development. 
 
2.  Education sector performance. Sri Lanka has made commendable gains in basic 
education  since  the  1970s.  It  has  achieved  near-universal  primary  enrollment  (99%),  high 
secondary enrollment (87%), gender parity in access to all levels of education, and a high adult 
literacy rate (93%). Despite these achievements, Sri Lanka lacks the technical and vocational 
skills  increasingly  demanded  in  industrial  and  service  sectors. 4  Poor  learning  outcome, 
inadequate foundation for twenty first skills and low relevance of education to the labor market 
are  key  challenges.  These  issues  are  exacerbated  by  a  fragmented  education  and  skills 
development system and the absence of a coordinated and coherent education policy to support 
holistic human capital development.  
 
3.  While overall access to basic education is high, limited participation in science, technology, 
engineering, and mathematics (STEM) subjects, low learning outcomes, and inadequacies in the 
quality and relevance are key challenges in secondary education. This situation is compounded 
by (i) limited opportunities for tertiary education, and (ii) inadequate pathways from secondary 
education to skills training and higher education. Student participation in tertiary education and 
post-secondary non-tertiary education (including skills training) measured by gross enrollment 
ratio (GER) were 19.6% (2018, 23.4% female) and 3.0% (2017, 2.6% female). In contrast, the 
tertiary GER average for UMICs was 58.1% in 2018.5 This leaves a large number of young people 
entering the job market without substantial employment skills. In sum, gains in basic education 
are not translating into comparable outcomes at the post-secondary level. While Sri Lanka has 
laid a good foundation for skills development with a dedicated ministry, a regulatory body and the 
delivery of TVET at different levels by various agencies, several challenges remain. These include: 
(i) poor alignment with the private sector; (ii) shortage of qualified instructors with industry 
experience; (iii) outdated training programs and facilities; (iv) weak quality assurance mechanisms; 
and (v) limited institutional capacities.

4.  Higher education plays an instrumental role in producing a future-ready workforce, but the 
government’s capacity to expand state university admissions, especially, in STEM subjects, is 
limited by constraints in funds, infrastructure, and trained academic staff. Unless higher education 
is realigned with evolving private sector needs, labor market outcomes will continue to be 
adverse.6 The  government’s  aim  to  improve  the  access,  quality,  and  relevance  of  higher 
education programs will require (i) establishing new degree programs and short courses in priority 
STEM programs; (ii) enabling the legal framework to promote private sector accreditation and 
provision;  (iii)  addressing  staff  shortage  and  professional  development  in  STEM;  (iv) 
benchmarking quality against international standards; and (v) public–private partnerships with 
industries to stimulate research and development.  
 
5.  Health sector performance. Sri Lanka has made impressive gains in ensuring access to 
quality health services for all. Life expectancy at birth increased from 70 years in 1990 to 75 years 
in 2015. Maternal mortality reduced from 75.0 to 30.0 per 100,000 live births, and infant mortality 
from 17.9 to 8.0 per 1,000 live births over the same period. Despite these improvements, Sri 
Lanka faces new health challenges related to population ageing, changing disease patterns, and 
changing lifestyles. These dynamics have resulted in the rise of noncommunicable diseases while 
re-emerging  and  emerging  communicable  diseases  remain  a  threat.  Health  disparities  are 
significant,  with  lagging  regions  and  vulnerable  population  pockets.  The  government  has 
introduced policy reform in 2018 to address the health challenges for a more responsive, people-
centered health care system that is evidence-based, delivers a comprehensive package of 
services, and can provide continuity of care with adequate financial risk protection for the users.7 
 
6.  Asian Development Bank’s assistance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been 
a long-term partner in education sector development in Sri Lanka, covering school education, 
skills development, and higher education. In the education sector, ADB currently supports the (i) 
Skills Sector Enhancement Program to ensure equitable access to high-quality and relevant 
demand-driven skills training; and (ii) Science and Technology Human Resource Development 
Project to nurture technology-oriented graduates equipped with market-relevant skills and an 
entrepreneurial spirit. With the approval of Health System Enhancement Project in 2018, ADB re-
engaged in the sector after 20 years and currently supports the government’s policy reform to 
reorganize health care delivery towards an equity-based, more responsive, and comprehensive 
primary health care system, in particular, in rural areas and lagging regions. New support has 
been proposed to ADB, namely the (i) Secondary Education Sector Improvement Program to 
enhance the quality and relevance of STEM subjects along with 21st century skills at the senior 
secondary level, essential for preparing Sri Lankan graduates for a knowledge economy; and (ii) 
proposed Innovation Capacity Development in Higher Education Project. 
 
7.  The government appreciated the design and implementation of ADB’s prior technical 
assistance (TA),8 which provided strategic technical inputs through resource persons and expert

consultants  for  project  preparation  and  implementation.  The  TA  is  near  completion.  The 
government has requested similar support.  Two key lessons emanated from the previous TA 
implementation. First, it is important to enhance the capacity of executing and implementing 
agencies in ensuring quality project design, effective project implementation, and overall portfolio 
performance. ADB support can add value in terms of sharing lessons across projects, introducing 
innovative approaches, strategic planning, and implementation support in selected areas. Second, 
ADB is in a strategic position to provide integrated and coordinated technical inputs across the 
three subsectors in education (secondary, TVET, and higher education) and health. Working 
across these three subsectors and with the health system, ADB can promote synergy, effective 
implementation, expanded private sector participation, and enhanced relevance and quality of 
education and health services, all of which will lead to the outcome of a stronger and healthy 
workforce to support national economic goals.  
 
8.  Rationale for a transaction technical assistance facility. The proposed transaction TA 
facility will support project preparation, capacity building, due diligence, and improved readiness 
for pipeline projects that are included in the country operations business plan (COBP),9 as agreed 
with the government during the TA facility’s timeframe. It will also support the implementation of 
ongoing projects.10 The TA facility is aligned with (i) ADB’s strategy 2030;11 (ii) the government’s 
Education Sector Development Plan, 2018–2025;12 (iii) Sri Lanka National Health Policy 2016–
2025;13 and (iv) Sustainable Development Goal 5.14 The TA facility will support strategic policy 
advisory and technical inputs on a range of health and education issues, strategy development, 
financial  management,  engineering  and  procurement,  quality  assurance,  and  evaluation 
approaches, including independent verification of results. It will bridge capability gaps, apply best 
practices, and foster innovative solutions for common challenges in the sector. In particular, the 
TA  will  bring  in  international  expertise  not  available  in-country  in  the  areas  of  curriculum, 
pedagogy, public–private partnerships, and healthcare reform. The TA facility is listed in the 
COBP for Sri Lanka, 2020–2022, with the title Support for Human Capital Development Initiative. 
The TA facility approach is suitable as it will enhance project preparation efficiency and improve 
project implementation readiness by (i) allowing the same experts to be mobilized for similar due 
diligence activities, (ii) facilitating learning on project processing and implementation across 
different projects, (iii) creating synergies from working with common expertise and improving 
knowledge transfer, and (iv) strengthening coordination and synergy among various technical 
inputs and capacity building efforts. Overall, this TA facility will reduce transaction costs compared 
to resources required for separate stand-alone transaction TA projects.

B.  Outputs and Activities 
9.  Output  1:  Improved  quality  of  program  and  project  design  in  social  sector 
operations. This output will support the preparation of selected programs and/or projects15 for 
potential ADB financing. The scope of activities will include (i) analytical studies such as sector 
assessments, technical assessments on curriculum, pedagogy, demand assessments involving 
tracer and/or employer surveys, TVET strategy, and stakeholder analysis as appropriate for each 
ensuing project; (ii) feasibility studies as required for the ensuing project; (iii) development of 
results  frameworks  and/or  design  and  monitoring  frameworks;  (iv)  economic  and  financial 
assessments, and social, gender, and poverty analyses; (v) safeguard assessments, including 
environment and social safeguards; and (vi) due diligence in financial management, procurement, 
plus other institutional arrangements for executing and implementing agencies. The output will 
also support projects to achieve project readiness through advance procurement activities, where 
required.   
 
10.  Output 2: Strengthened project management capacity for achieving quality results 
in social sector operations. Technical expertise and capacity building support will be provided 
to selected executing and implementing agencies for the successful implementation of health and 
education projects. Selective, high-quality inputs will support the achievement of results in 
secondary education, skills, higher education, and health. At the same time, the TA will support 
quality assurance mechanisms and systems, such as the verification of disbursement-linked 
indicators,  monitoring  and  evaluation  approaches/systems,  financial  management,  and 
procurement. Having a single TA facility will ensure coordinated and integrated inputs across the 
various education subsectors, which will promote the synergy of results.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Enhanced  capacity  to  develop  and  apply  innovative  practices  and 
technology  solutions  for  project  design  and  implementation.  Technical  expertise  and 
capacity  building  will  support  the  exchange  of  national  and  international  best  practices  in 
secondary education, skills training, and higher education. The topics will cover: (i) learner 
centered approaches that build 21st century skills, including critical thinking and problem solving; 
(ii) inquiry-based and investigative pedagogy, including long-term, sustained approach to building 
capacity of  teachers that will include opportunities to practice new approaches and a focus on 
coaching  and  ongoing  feedback  mechanism  to  improve  teaching  in  the  classroom;    (iii) 
information  and  communication  technology  solutions  for  education  and  health  sectors  (for 
example, EdTech programs in classroom practices and teacher training); and (iv) cutting-edge 
monitoring and evaluation approaches or platforms. The output will promote innovative strategies 
to improve learning outcomes and 21st century skills aligned with the modern global economy, 
expand  post-secondary  pathways,  improve  the  effectiveness  of  pedagogy  and  leadership 
programs, increase the participation of girls in STEM, and address the low performance and 
dropout of boys. Much of the support will be provided through technical inputs and guidance on-
the-job during planning, implementation, and coaching. Some support will be provided through 
seminars, workshops, and national and overseas study visits. This output will also document good 
design and implementation of projects to showcase innovative strategies and solutions in the 
health and education sectors. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a 
 
grant basis by ADB’s TA Special Fund (TASF-other sources).The key expenditure items are listed 
 
15  (i) Proposed Secondary Education Sector Improvement Program; (ii) Proposed Innovation Capacity Development in 
Higher Education Project; and (iii) potential new program for skills training.

5 
in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office  space,  office  supplies,  secretarial  and  coordination  assistance,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The executing agency will be the National Planning Department under the Ministry of 
Finance. The implementing agencies are the Ministry of Education; Ministry of Skills Development, 
Employment and Labour Relations; Ministry of Higher Education, Technology and Innovation; and 
the Ministry of Health and Indigenous Medical Services. ADB will administer the TA facility. The 
South  Asia  Human  and  Social  Development  Division  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate 
consultants in close coordination with the executing and implementing agencies. The TA facility 
will be implemented over 3 years, from May 2020 to April 2023.

15.  Consulting  services.  The  TA  facility  will  provide  a  total  of  135.7  person-months’ 
consultant inputs (39.2 person-months international and 96.5 person-months national) to support 
the preparation and implementation of the ensuing projects. The consultants will be recruited 
using individual consultant selection method and deployed based on the requirements of each 
project being prepared or implemented. Individual consultant selection, rather than firm selection, 
is  considered  appropriate,  because  the  TA  facility  involves  multiple  activities  that  are  not 
necessarily interdependent and will require a varied range of consultants and services. ADB will 
engage  the  consultants  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  and  Regulations  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.16  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for the Support for Human Capital Development Initiative, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
